title: How to Recycle Labels

steps.headline: Check the recycling guidelines in your area.
steps.description: The best way to find out if a label is recyclable is to look up the specific recycling rules for your area. Go online and type “recycling guidelines” followed by your city into a search engine. Your area’s recycling website will list all of the items that can be recycled, as well as those that can’t.

steps.headline: Keep the labels on most recyclables.
steps.description: The recycling process has become more advanced, and it’s not necessary to remove most labels when recycling. If the label is small or moisture-activated, it’s definitely safe to recycle. Things such as postage stamps or Post-It sticky notes can be recycled.

steps.headline: Remove super sticky labels or large labels on cardboard packaging.
steps.description: Labels on things like packages or large boxes should be taken off, along with all of the tape. If a label is larger than usual and also has a super sticky backing, it’s a good idea to remove these labels as well. Discard the labels in the trash, or recycle them through a DIY project. Things such as stickers aren’t usually recyclable.

steps.headline: Group paper labels with your regular paper recycling.
steps.description: Labels made of paper, like the ones on soup cans, can be taken off and put with your other paper recyclables. Tear the paper off of the glass, metal, or plastic to remove it. When recycling plastic, glass, or metal, the paper is burned off of the container, making it okay to recycle paper labels. If the label has a small section—roughly less than 2–3 inches (5.1–7.6 cm)—that's sticky, this is okay.

steps.headline: Throw out the label and container if you’re unsure.
steps.description: If you think a label might be recyclable but really don’t know, it’s better just to remove it before recycling the container or paper. If the label can’t be taken off, just throw out the entire item. Labels that can’t be recycled end up messing up the machines, which is why it’s best to throw away a labeled item if you’re not sure if it’s recyclable.

steps.headline: Pull off or cut out labels on paper, if necessary.
steps.description: If you’re able to pull labels off of paper products, such as cardboard, go for it! If they don’t pull off easily, you may need to use scissors to cut the entire label off. Once the label is off, you can recycle the paper. Discard the sticky label in the trash.

steps.headline: Soak labels in a washing soda mixture if they’re on glass.
steps.description: Fill a tub big enough to fit the glass container with hot water before pouring in 1 cup (240 ml) of washing soda. Mix the washing soda into the water and place the glass container with the label on it in the water. Take the glass out after 30 minutes, and the label should slide off easily. Washing soda is a chemical compound used for washing and cleaning. You can find it in grocery stores or big box stores. If you’re trying to get the label off of a small glass container, you can use 0.5  c (120 ml) of washing soda—the measurements don’t have to be exact, so feel free to improvise.

steps.headline: Fill plastic containers with hot water to easily pull off labels.
steps.description: Pour hot water into the plastic container and put the lid back on securely. Lay the container on its side so that the label is face-down. Let the hot water sit inside the container for 15 minutes before trying to peel the label off carefully. When pulling the label off, start at an end and go slowly to keep it intact.

steps.headline: Use a hair dryer to heat up metal containers to remove labels.
steps.description: Turn your heat gun or hair dryer onto medium/high heat and apply the heat to the label for a minute or two. Once the metal is warm, begin at a corner and slowly peel the label off. Don’t attempt to do this on plastic, as the plastic may melt once high heat is applied.

steps.headline: Remove sticky residue from labels using baking soda and oil.
steps.description: Mix together 1 part baking soda and 1 part oil in a small container. Apply this paste to the sticky residue left from removing the label, using your fingers to massage it over the residue. Rinse the container under clean running water to remove the baking soda and oil paste. You can use any type of oil, such as vegetable oil, olive oil, or canola oil. When you’re applying the paste, you should feel the residue come off and the surface will feel smooth.

steps.headline: Create magnets using the labels.
steps.description: Purchase small, plain magnets from a home improvement or craft store. Glue a label onto the magnet, cutting around the magnet so that the label fits it perfectly. Use a craft glue or clear sealant to attach the labels to the magnets. Magnets are perfect for super small labels.

steps.headline: Use craft glue to cover drink coasters with recycled labels.
steps.description: Purchase plain drink coasters, or recycle ones you already own, and paint them with a craft glue. Place the label overtop the drink coasters and cover them with another layer of clear craft glue, cutting around the edges of the drink coaster to remove excess label if necessary. Use can or jar labels to cover the entire coaster, or use smaller labels to create a collage on the coaster.

steps.headline: Decorate cards or scrapbooks using the labels.
steps.description: If you have labels that have a creative or pleasing design on them, such as a wine label, you can tape or glue them onto the front of cards or scrapbook pages. Use double-sided tape or a small amount of craft glue to attach the labels to the paper. Cut the labels into shapes such as hearts or circles before attaching them to a card or scrapbook page, if desired.

steps.headline: Cover canvases with recycled labels for decorative artwork.
steps.description: If you have lots of recycled labels that you’ve removed from plastics, metals, glass, or paper, you can use craft glue to collage them onto a plain canvas. Choose a cloth or wooden canvas in a size that you like, and cover it with craft glue before putting the labels on top. Once the labels are on the canvas, cover them with a clear craft glue to protect the art. Cover a canvas with all wine labels, or create a canvas with all of your favorite brands.

text: Separating the Recycling with Labels Check the recycling guidelines in your area. The best way to find out if a label is recyclable is to look up the specific recycling rules for your area. Go online and type “recycling guidelines” followed by your city into a search engine. Your area’s recycling website will list all of the items that can be recycled, as well as those that can’t. Keep the labels on most recyclables. The recycling process has become more advanced, and it’s not necessary to remove most labels when recycling. If the label is small or moisture-activated, it’s definitely safe to recycle. Things such as postage stamps or Post-It sticky notes can be recycled. Remove super sticky labels or large labels on cardboard packaging. Labels on things like packages or large boxes should be taken off, along with all of the tape. If a label is larger than usual and also has a super sticky backing, it’s a good idea to remove these labels as well. Discard the labels in the trash, or recycle them through a DIY project. Things such as stickers aren’t usually recyclable. Group paper labels with your regular paper recycling. Labels made of paper, like the ones on soup cans, can be taken off and put with your other paper recyclables. Tear the paper off of the glass, metal, or plastic to remove it. When recycling plastic, glass, or metal, the paper is burned off of the container, making it okay to recycle paper labels. If the label has a small section—roughly less than 2–3 inches (5.1–7.6 cm)—that's sticky, this is okay. Throw out the label and container if you’re unsure. If you think a label might be recyclable but really don’t know, it’s better just to remove it before recycling the container or paper. If the label can’t be taken off, just throw out the entire item. Labels that can’t be recycled end up messing up the machines, which is why it’s best to throw away a labeled item if you’re not sure if it’s recyclable. Taking Labels off Pull off or cut out labels on paper, if necessary. If you’re able to pull labels off of paper products, such as cardboard, go for it! If they don’t pull off easily, you may need to use scissors to cut the entire label off. Once the label is off, you can recycle the paper. Discard the sticky label in the trash. Soak labels in a washing soda mixture if they’re on glass. Fill a tub big enough to fit the glass container with hot water before pouring in 1 cup (240 ml) of washing soda. Mix the washing soda into the water and place the glass container with the label on it in the water. Take the glass out after 30 minutes, and the label should slide off easily. Washing soda is a chemical compound used for washing and cleaning. You can find it in grocery stores or big box stores. If you’re trying to get the label off of a small glass container, you can use 0.5  c (120 ml) of washing soda—the measurements don’t have to be exact, so feel free to improvise. Fill plastic containers with hot water to easily pull off labels. Pour hot water into the plastic container and put the lid back on securely. Lay the container on its side so that the label is face-down. Let the hot water sit inside the container for 15 minutes before trying to peel the label off carefully. When pulling the label off, start at an end and go slowly to keep it intact. Use a hair dryer to heat up metal containers to remove labels. Turn your heat gun or hair dryer onto medium/high heat and apply the heat to the label for a minute or two. Once the metal is warm, begin at a corner and slowly peel the label off. Don’t attempt to do this on plastic, as the plastic may melt once high heat is applied. Remove sticky residue from labels using baking soda and oil. Rinse the container under clean running water to remove the baking soda and oil paste. You can use any type of oil, such as vegetable oil, olive oil, or canola oil. When you’re applying the paste, you should feel the residue come off and the surface will feel smooth. Reusing the Labels Create magnets using the labels. Purchase small, plain magnets from a home improvement or craft store. Glue a label onto the magnet, cutting around the magnet so that the label fits it perfectly. Use a craft glue or clear sealant to attach the labels to the magnets. Magnets are perfect for super small labels. Use craft glue to cover drink coasters with recycled labels. Use can or jar labels to cover the entire coaster, or use smaller labels to create a collage on the coaster. Decorate cards or scrapbooks using the labels. Use double-sided tape or a small amount of craft glue to attach the labels to the paper. Cut the labels into shapes such as hearts or circles before attaching them to a card or scrapbook page, if desired. Cover canvases with recycled labels for decorative artwork. Choose a cloth or wooden canvas in a size that you like, and cover it with craft glue before putting the labels on top. Once the labels are on the canvas, cover them with a clear craft glue to protect the art. Cover a canvas with all wine labels, or create a canvas with all of your favorite brands.
